qas.question: Who was the Soviet Union's opponent in the Cold War?
How many nuclear warheads can be made with 540 metric tons of highly enriched weapons grade uranium?
What was the expenditure of the Material Protection, Control, and Accounting Program between 1993 and 2005?
What is another term for uranium that is enriched?
Approximately how many times did police capture shipments of bomb-grade plutonium or uranium between 1993 and 2005?
Who was the Soviet Union's ally in the Cold War?
How many nuclear warheads can be made with 450 metric tons of highly enriched weapons grade uranium?
What was the expenditure of the Material Protection, Control, and Accounting Program between 1995 and 2005?
What is another term for uranium that is not enriched?
Approximately how many times did police capture shipments of bomb-grade plutonium or uranium between 1993 and 2003?

context: During the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the <a0_0><b5_0>United States<b5_0/><a0_0/>, huge stockpiles of uranium were amassed and tens of thousands of nuclear weapons were created using enriched uranium and plutonium made from uranium. Since the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991, an estimated 600 short tons (540 metric tons) of highly enriched weapons grade uranium (enough to make <a1_0><b6_0>40,000<b6_0/><a1_0/> nuclear warheads) have been stored in often inadequately guarded facilities in the Russian Federation and several other former Soviet states. Police in Asia, Europe, and South America on at least <a4_0><b9_0>16<b9_0/><a4_0/> occasions from 1993 to 2005 have intercepted shipments of smuggled bomb-grade uranium or plutonium, most of which was from ex-Soviet sources. From 1993 to 2005 the Material Protection, Control, and Accounting Program, operated by the federal government of the United States, spent approximately <a2_0><b7_0>US $550 million<b7_0/><a2_0/> to help safeguard uranium and plutonium stockpiles in Russia. This money was used for improvements and security enhancements at research and storage facilities. Scientific American reported in February 2006 that in some of the facilities security consisted of chain link fences which were in severe states of disrepair. According to an interview from the article, one facility had been storing samples of enriched (<a3_0><b8_0>weapons grade<b8_0/><a3_0/>) uranium in a broom closet before the improvement project; another had been keeping track of its stock of nuclear warheads using index cards kept in a shoe box.
